epigraph.l: These are thy glorious works parent of good

lg.l: 1WHEN First the wrath of heavʼn oerwhelmed the world,
And oer the rocks and hills and mountains hurled
The waters gathering mass and sea oer shore[--]
Then mountains fell, and Vales unknown before,
5Lay Where they were. Far different was the earth
When first the flood came down than at its second Birth.
Now for its produce. Queen of flowers O rose[--]
From Whose fair coloured leaves such odour flows,
Thou must now be before thy subjects Named[--]
10Both for thy beauty and thy sweetness famed.
Thou art the flower of england and the flowʼr
Of Beauty Too[,] of Venus odrous Bower[--]
And Thou Wilt often shed Sweet odours Round,
lg.fw: TIGER LILY GENTIAN BLUEBELL YUCCA FILIMENTOSA DALIA & SNOWBERRY
lg.l: And often stooping hide thy head on ground.
15And then the Lily towering up so proud[--]
And raising its gay head among the various crowd
OF flowers sweet. All opening to the day,
Both to the morning and the suns fair ray.
There the Black spots upon a scarlet ground,
20And there the taper pointed leaves are found.
Then thou sweet flower the gentian come in view,
With thy gay hanging Bells of Brightest Blue[--]
And thy sweet Sister Blue Bell comes with thee,
Both are great Beauties for Mankind to see.
25And then sweet Maid the Yucca dressed in white,
With fibrous leaves And Dazzled By the light[--]
Eerect and straight thou standest mid the flowers,
While oer the rest thy lofty head‐bell towrʼs.
Among the rest the high‐topped dalia [i.e., dahlia] shows,
30With huesʼ almost superior to the rose.
Its velvet leaves of finest crimson dye
Around a circle of bright yellow lie.
Thy pink and white fair snowberry Appears[--]
Cheering The eye for many running years.
lg.fw: LAURUSTINUS SNOWDROP LILAC & RED PRIMROSE & HYACINTH
lg.l: 35Thy balls of marble and Thy blooming pink,
Will make us oft of thy creator think.
The laurustinus white I next will name,
Although it has not just too much of fame[--]
Its buds are brown Its flowers are snowy white[--]
40It opens at young Januarys light.
The hanging snowdrop at length must appear,
In spite of all its modest maidlike fear[--]
It hangs its head upon a stalk of green[--]
Its head a bell of purest white is seen.
45The lilac primrose on a thick laid bed,
Of clustered leaves doth rest Its pretty head,
Beside its sister called primrose red.
And by the By before I should have named
Young hyacinthus by Apollo famed,
50Who by the discus stroke did strike him dead[--]
And made this flower from his dying head,
And called it hyacinth. And some are Blue.
And some are White and Pink unto the view[--]
They incline downwards from a stalk full straight,
55Sad flowers created from the youths sad fate.
lg.fw: CROCUS PERIWINKLE HEARTSEASE VIOLET JONQUIL NARCISSUS & DAFFODIL
lg.l: The yellow crocus flames in flowers of gold.
Its formed in a pretty cupshaped mould
One flowers in january, its brother then
Flowers in autumnal light autumnal ken.
60The fiveleaved Periwinkle coloured blue
With stalk of green and beauteous to the view
Amidst a cluster of the finest green
Hides its sweet head and dislikes to be seen
The heartsease sweet it well deserves the name
65For such a beauty hardlys known to fame
Its dyes are gold and purple and with these
Mingled are stripes of black, its name, heartsease
Then comes the violet the purple maid
Upon a bed of leaves its head is laid
70And while the flower casts its odours round
The lowly plant neer leaves its mother ground
The jonquil Sometimes has an ugly name
Which from its white and yellow mingled came
Butter and eggs it is at other times
75Narcissus called and its remaining lines
Are called daffodil. It hath a floweʼr
lg.fw: WALLFLOWER CROWN IMPERIAL YELLOW ALYSSON[i.e., alyssum] COLUMBINE AND LILY OF THE VALLEY
lg.l: That from a stalk foot high its head doth lowr
And of the brightest yellow is the flowʼr
The wall‐flower in its clusters cometh then
80Sweet to the smell and sweet to human ken
Brown and bright yellow are its mingled dyes
There even brown is pretty to the eyes
The crown imperial hangs its noble head
Some insects are by its white milk drops fed
85For in the bells of each large yellow flower
Four seeming milkdrops have their noble bower
These insects feed on, and they gather quick
While each applies the liquid to the lip
A lowly clustered flower now takes its place
90I mean the alysson [i.e., alyssum] with a yellow face
This flower in thickest yellow cluster grows
And only its old mother earth well knows
A purple flower I now make known to fame
Tis sometimes white and tis known by the name
95Of columbine in pods kept are its seeds
And sometimes columbines are really weeds
The lily of the valley now doth come
lg.fw: FLAG COMERFREY GERANIUM T GREEK VaLERIAN & LILY OF THE VALLEY
lg.l: Its large leaves hide its face quite from the sun
Beautiful maid so modest and so sweet
100And greatly dreading mortal eyes to meet
Green pointed leaves around its flowers grow
And from its pretty bells such odours flow
As might have sent great Jupiter to sleep
When all the world was fighting at his feet
105A purple colour doth the flag adorn
It looks like velvet opening to the morn
So rich the colour that it feeds the eye
Every one should be sad that it must die.
Then in the comfrey mixed are blue and red
110Odd colours that in flowers they should wed
But when together they are quite as sweet
As both the colours are when they dont meet
Crimson geranium long and pretty name
OnThis flowʼr is sometimes called bill of the crane
115Or cranesbill. Lightish crimson is its hue
Anotherʼs colour is a kind of blue
Now comes the flower with a noble name
Name of the nation thats most known to fame
lg.fw: HONEYSUCKLE TURKSCAP LILY PROVENCE ROSE INDIAN PINK & GUELDER ROSE
lg.l: 120I mean the Greeks This flowers colours blue
And tis indeed a very beauteous hue
The climbing honeysuckle now doth come
Exposing all its flowers to the sun
Its flower various tubes theiʼr coloured pink
125And it is very beautiful I think
You turkscap lily [i.e, Turkʼs‐cap lily], Turk although you be
Yet your a royal turk eʼen I can see
Your beauteous caps in clusters thick and fair
130You are too noble for Atrides hair
And Oh the province [i.e., provence] rose The flake of snow
From which such overpowʼring odours flow
Thou must now beauteous wondrous flowr
The only place yourʼe fit for is for Venus bowʼr.
135YouThou Indian pink an honour to that land
Putting to shame all done by mortal hand
And its sweet head of such a crimson hue
Tis wonderful that from a seed it grew
Then Gilder [i.e., guelder] rose small flowers connected all
140And when connected their shape is a ball
As white as snow something like provence rose
In a large bush this noble flower grows
Then the sweet William like the Indian Pink
In colour but much larger I do think
145And different shape But all are fairest fair
All natures beauties are united there
And then the noisy instrument of fame
All all will know the trumpet is its name
This is the trumpet flowr so named because
150Its shape extremely near the trumpet draws
And now that flowr Flowr indeed of sleep
Flower to make too many mothers weep
You deady [i.e., deadly] poppy Poison though you be
Yet yourʼe a beauty for mankind to see
155Now comes the foxglove with its hanging bells
But ah alas its nature poison tells
Attractive beautiful but poisʼnous too
Foxglove I would not dare to play with you
Now comes the king of flowrs Though rose the queen
160A nobler king will neer will neer be seen
White lily tis Oh look at that fair crown
From that green stalk so high depending down
Fair on its dark green leaves that crimson flowr
Darts bright upon the eye and whiles away an hour
165Glaring it rises from its leafy bed
And always seems as if to you it said.
I know that I am beautiful & see
Whether a flower can compare with me
See my green leaves and see my head beside
170With such a crimson such a glorious tide
That which another in thou canst not see
For not another flower is like me.
That the rose is a maiden fair tis true
And almost equals me But then judge you
175Whether my darker colour doth not beat
Een that fair flowr where most beauties meet
Now say I Dost thou compare with the rose
Alas what flower itself really knows
That glaring crimson which you seem to like
180Know that it glares too much unto the sight
While that fair flowr its maiden pink bestows
With such a sweetness as beseems the rose
Now sir hang down your head and dare no more
To put yourself the beauteous rose before
185There is a tree & famed it was of old
It used the brows of conqʼrors to enfold
I need not name it Tis the tree of him
Who doth preside oer music and to sing
The God who did the Pythoness inspire
190From the dark cavern with his sacred fire
As tis his tree it folds the poetʼs brow
And is the tree of fame Enough ofʼt now.
High in the air the poplar nobly towʼrs
And seems for loftiness the King of flowrs
195Its head contends to reach the clouds on high
And seems ambitious een to touch the sky—
Now the broad Oak displays its arms around
Its brawny branches spreading sweep the ground
Its Kingly arms their giant strength display
200With their great breadth een hide the face of day
Broad round the mother trunk they throw their arms
And dare encounter dreadful wars alarms
To their assistance England owes her strength
The spoils of nations come from their dread length
205Of them are formed Englands wooden walls
With them surrounded England loves Mars calls
Clothed in that armour of approved strength
The British conquests have unbounded length
In vain the waves attempt to break their sides
210And to oerwhelm them with the rushing tides
A copper armour keeps them safe below
They look down proud not frighted as they go
There the stern‐front the rushing sea divides
And towering high provokes the foaming tides
215High at the stern they rear then sink below
Then rise again and then around they go
Foaming with rage that mortals should surmount
The watʼry deep and sail the seas about
Unheeding of their rage the oak sails on
220And Britons triumphing by seas are borne
END OF THE FIRST BOOK
I SING the pine which clothes high switzers head
And high enthroned grows on a rocky bed
On gulfs so deep on cliffs that are so high
He that would dare to climb them dares to die
5There they hang oer the dreadful rocky steeps
There they bend over and they kiss the deeps
Which round the rocks do play and raging still
Awake the echoes from the wavy hill.
But man this pleasing picture soon would spoil
10Regardless both of beauty and of toil
Though nature tried in vain to preserve them for a while
In vain to save them she did place them high
Alas in vain for they were doomed to die
Man formed a slide huge pondʼrous to behold
15It cost much labour and it cost much gold
Along the breast of Pilates cliff it lay
Oero rocks and gulfs and glens it held its way
And ended in Lucerne, on this the trees
Roaring like thunder borne upon the breeze
20Rushed down and rushing dreadful in their ire
To their assistance such their anger dire
Summoned with red and flaming crown that monster fire
He then would have been king and on the mount
The flaming forests would have spread about
25Another Etna Pilate would have been
Oer spacious Switzerland the fires are seen
In one sad ruin all the pines would fall
In vain for help the noble forests call
But man had this foreseen. Ingenious man
30Thought, can I this prevent. Yes if I will I can
And so man made the mountain streams descend
And down the trough their dangʼrous course to bend
This element opposed the raging fire
And did prevent its great effects so dire
35Now comes the hawthorn with its blossoms white
Welcoming gaily in Mays cheerful light
With luscious odours it perfumes the breeze
Most fair most cheerful sweetest of the trees
Bound up with clusters white it doth adorn
40The tall pole which is raised on Mays first morn
And lightly bounding from the blooming green
Round it the village youth are dancing seen.
Dandily dressed with scarlet ribbons gay
The sweeps with hawthorn welcome in the may
45With fluttering rags with yellow & with red
And hawthorn blossoms waving oer their head
Rattling their shovels they do dance about
And think their robes are very fine no doubt.
And now the Yew a mournful tree I sing
50Which poisʼnous is to every living thing
And meet it is that such a tree is placed
In the dread church yard where the corses waste
Now think again in every case the Yew
Shows death in all its terrors to the view
55For lo see there Just bursting from the wood
The free and lawless band of Robin Hood
Look at their bows tough Yew confines the string
And Yew elastic gives the arrow wing
Well aimed and thirsting for the purple blood
60Of tallest stag that ever ranged the wood
The winged dart flies gladly through the air
And quickly fixes in its body fair
The tall stag fainteth with the deadly wound
And deeply sighing sinks upon the ground
65And thus oppressed by the winged death
The dying stag sobs forth its latest breath
And now dost see yon ruined pile on high
Majestic creeping up against the sky
Behold the Ivy creeping oer the stone
70Which still remains from Luxury thats gone
Where now foul weeds arise and tempests sweep
Oer the vast hall and tower & donjon keep
In former times were feasts and blazing fires
And mirth and everything the soul desires
75Time hath flown by with mouldering touch hath past
And mirth & luxury have breathed their last
